prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Imaging requirements: We plan to resolve the N2H+ depleted hole, if it exists, in the core center and its diameter is roughly greater than 500 AU in the model (Fig. 7). Thus, we need a 2" angular resolution to resolve the structure for the source located in the Perseus molecular cloud (250 pc) where most of our proposed targets are located. Note that Ophiuchus is much closer to us than Perseus. Requested sensitivity: We estimate our required sensitivity by assuming that our targets have a similar N2H+ (1-0) intensity to IRAM04191 (Fig. 7, PdBI: Belloch et al. 2004). We first transfer the peak integrated intensity in PdBI beam (0.6 Jy/beam km/s at 5.8”×4”) to an intensity of 5.3 K km/s. We assume the line width of N2H+ as 0.37 km/s for our targets, which is from IRAM 30m observations toward DCE065, 064 and 081 (Johnstone et al. 2010). We thus estimate the peak intensity of N2H+ to be 14.3 K. Using the PdBI map as a typical example for all VeLLOs, to map the ring-like depletion structure (S/N=12) confidently, the required noise level is 1.2 K for 2" angular resolution.

Imaging requirements: We request the same angular resolution as that of N2H+ observations in order to fairly compare the N2D+ and N2H+ profiles. Requested sensitivity: Since N2D+ (3-2) is typically weaker than CO (2-1), we estimate our integration time using N2D+ (3-2) at band 6. We assume the line strength of N2D+ (3-2) for all VeLLOs are similar. From our SMA result of DCE065, the peak flux in our channel map is 0.49 Jy/beam with a channel width of 0.26 km/s. Assuming that the intensity is distributed uniformly throughout the area of the beam (4.35”×3.42”), and the missing flux is negligible, we estimate the intensity of N2D+ (3-2) to be 0.042 Jy arcsec−2 (1.09 K). To achive our goals, we request the observations with a S/N ∼ 7 (rms = 0.156 K) with 2” angular resolution.
the same as, SG N2H+ Perseus
the same as SG, N2D+ Perseus

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to observe CO (2-1), N2D+ (3-2) and N2H+ (1-0) toward 12 Luminosity Objects (LLOs, Lint < 0.2 Lsun), which are the faintest embedded YSOs currently known. With their low luminosities, VeLLOs are believed to either have very low mass protostars or be extremely young protostars. N2D+ and N2H+ provide reliable evolutionary information in the early stage, thus can be used to indicate the ages of YSOs at the beginning of their formation. CO traces the outflows and jets, which are important mechanisms in the removal of angular momentum from the core collapsing process in star formation. We plan to use N2D+/N2H+ and N2H+ profiles as our age indicators to explore whether VeLLOs' low luminosity is caused by their mass or their age. Together with chemical age indicators, we are able to trace the youngest outflows and study the outflow evolution. Our proposed observations provide important information of outflow morphology and protostar evolution in the very early stage of YSOs.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2012.1.00243.S, Studying Chemical Properties and Outflow Morphology in VeLLOs, Tien-Hao Hsieh

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute of Astronomy, National Tsing-Hua University

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute of Astronomy, National Tsing-Hua University
